head.label.name: ยง
head.headtext: Covenants Entered Into After Formation of the Employment Relationship

para.paratext: The courts will distinguish covenants made prior to commencement of an employment relationship from those entered into afterward. Where a person is already employed, the courts will take a careful look at the circumstances that resulted in the signing of any additional covenants. Unless a right to amend the contract of employment can be implied, or the employee offers his or her consent to the amendment, the courts will normally look for additional consideration to the employee if they are to avoid a conclusion that the covenant was imposed unilaterally by the employer.[1] Accordingly, it is best to impose a restrictive covenant at the beginning of the employment relationship. If protection is desired later, there must be some form of consideration, such as a promotion or financial incentive, to justify imposition of the new covenant. In all cases, the circumstances of the signing should be fair.
Gentle v. Mediacom Industries Inc. (1983), 24 A.C.W.S. (2d) 188 (Ont. H.C.J.); Johnston v. Merit Clothing Co. (1984), 24 A.C.W.S. (2d) 50 (Ont. S.C.).
